results.title: The Language of maps
results.brief_description: Uses aerial photography, topographic models and maps to show that the language of maps is composed of symbols representing natural and man-made features of the earth’s surface.

results.title: The Language of Japan
results.brief_description: Shows the history and development of the language of Japan, in both spoken and written forms. Defines and illustrates Japanese literary traditions, and shows the highly refined art form of calligraphy.

results.title: The Language of film: the technique of super 8 production
results.creator_credit: Playing With Time and Kit Hood
results.brief_description: Follows a group of 12-16 year old student filmmakers through the various stages of creating their own 8mm film. Looks at three major areas: pre-production (scriptwriting, props and equipment); production (camera shots, direction, actors, assistants); and post-production (editing, sound). Narrated by Linda Schuyler. Suitable for secondary level.

results.title: The Language of advertising (TEFC)
results.creator_credit: Michael Dibb and British Broadcasting Corporation
results.brief_description:
Episode number 4 of Series “Ways of seeing”.
One of a series of films by art critic and author, John Berger, which explores the ways in which we look at pictures. Shows how the images used in advertising and publicity are related to the tradition of oil painting, a connection which we fail to notice only because we are encouraged to believe that painting is fine art whereas publicity is simple commerce. Suitable for upper secondary and tertiary levels.

results.title: The Landscape architects
results.creator_credit: Mike Weatherley and British Broadcasting Corporation
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Up a gum tree”.
Australia owes a great debt to the Aboriginals who learned to tame the inhospitable countryside. But why did they never become farmers and what sort of diet did the first Australians enjoy? David Bellamy attempts to find out the answers to these questions.

results.title: The Land: the South Pembrokeshire coast
results.creator_credit: Julia Spark, Granada International Productions and Richard Guinea
results.brief_description: This film concentrates on the main features of the coastal landscape of the south Pembrokeshire coast of southwestern Wales, showing how the two different rock types: old red sandstone and carboniferous limestone, have reacted to the erosive forces of wind, wave and weather. Suitable for secondary level.

results.title: The Land: South Lancashire coast
results.creator_credit: Julia Spark, Granada International Productions and Richard Guinea
results.brief_description: This film shows how man has adapted the south Lancashire coastline to meet the needs of work and recreation. The large industrial dockland complex of Liverpool shows how man has completely altered the coastal environment in order to satisfy his economic needs. Suitable for secondary level.

results.title: The Land: Cumbrian Lake District
results.creator_credit: Julia Spark, Granada Television International and Richard Guinea
results.brief_description: This film shows the distinctive landform features which have been produced by Ice Age glaciation in the Lake District in England. Explanations are given of the processes which have produced such geographical features; the impact of humans through tourism is also looked at. Presented by Bill Grundy.

results.title: The Land: a new priority
results.creator_credit: Roman Bittman, ONF | NFB and Roger Hart
results.brief_description: This documentary concerns the struggle of rural people in the Third World. The film takes us into the rural communities of Senegal, Kenya, Mauritius, Pakistan, and Sri Lanka, where foreign and local aid programs, combined with imaginative community projects, initiate small but significant changes. The brilliance of local dress, the traditional songs and dances, and the beautiful green images fail to mask the very real difficulty of finding a day’s food.
